content.description: A recent article published in Berry Weekly reported a probability distribution for the different types of jelly that individuals prefer. Editors from a competitive magazine, Jammin, conducted their own study to test the distribution. The editors from Jammin surveyed a random sample of 50 individuals and recorded the observed counts of individuals for each jelly type. They decided to test Berry Weekly’s claim using a chi-square goodness-of-fit test using Jammin’s observed counts compared with the number of expected counts based on the Berry Weekly data.
content.question: Berry Weekly Expected Counts Jammin Observed Counts Strawberry (S) 16.5 18 Grape (G) 11 12 Wild Berry (WB) 9.5 8 Peach (P) 7.5 6 Other (O) 5.5 6 Which of the following is the correct null hypothesis for the test?

choices.label: <math alttext="H sub 0: p sub S equals 0.165, p sub G equals 0.11, p sub W B equals 0.095, p sub p equals 0.075, p sub O equals 0.055" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>0</mn></mrow></msub><mo>:</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.165</mn><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>G</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.11</mn><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>W</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.095</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.075</mn><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>O</mi></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><mn>0.055</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 8.2: Setting up a Chi-Square Goodness of Fit Test

skill.text: Skill 1.F: Identify null and alternative hypotheses.
